report_title: Industry Report on Invoice Factoring in the US
executive_summary: While invoice factoring companies offer a unique financial product, they've been facing major threats during the current period. Greater access to credit has enabled more consumers to use commercial banking and other forms of lending with ease. Since these institutions provide more products and greater stability, many businesses decided to receive funds from them instead of invoice factoring companies, causing revenue for the industry to plunge. COVID-19 also disrupted the industry by disturbing downstream markets and reducing business sentiment, though lower corporate profit constrained external competition. High inflation has been discouraging some corporations from using invoice factoring because of expensive fees.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising Access to Credit Has Made Substitutes More Attractive
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Access to credit has expanded during the current period as a result of increased financial innovation. This includes better consumer access to financial technology products. More access to credit has raised the borrowing capacity advanced by commercial banks in the form of loans, cash credit and overdrafts. Since traditional financial institutions have been offering more funds, businesses have been moving toward the industry's competitors, siphoning revenue away from invoice factoring companies.

The onset of the pandemic caused state and local governments to shut down businesses and enforce quarantines, drastically reducing revenue for many industries. In turn, this constrained demand for invoice factoring companies in the United States. There was major economic uncertainty during COVID-19, so growth in business sentiment was meager, contributing to declining revenue for the industry in 2020.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Inflation Has Made Invoice Factoring Too Expensive for Many
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Inflation has soared recently as a rapidly reopening post-pandemic economy could not meet a surge in consumer demand. Persistent supply chain issues arose since COVID-19 and were exacerbated by the war in Ukraine. Expansive monetary policy and excessive government spending caused demand throughout the economy to surge, contributing to high inflation. Since invoice factoring companies sometimes charge high fees for their services, many businesses have strayed away from using the industry's services to keep their budgets in check, contributing to falling revenue during the current period.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Higher Interest Rates Have Provided a Glimmer of Hope
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: To combat high inflation, the Federal Reserve has increased interest rates dramatically in 2022 and 2023. This follows a period of very low borrowing costs since the 2008 financial crisis, specifically during COVID-19. As the cost of borrowing has gone up recently, some businesses and consumers have lost access to traditional financial products. Invoice factoring companies will sell to customers who can't afford the high rates offered to them by commercial banks. Since many businesses have been locked out by borrowing costs, new revenue streams have been popping up for the industry.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Industry Will Buckle Under Increased External Competition
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Despite challenges related to high inflation, rising interest rates and recessionary fears, the US economy will perform well during the outlook period. Steadily rising GDP will boost consumer spending, increasing business sales and corporate profit. Higher corporate profit will give companies the funds to use traditional financial products, taking revenue away from the industry.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Greater Consolidation Will Provide Better Opportunities
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Since the market for invoice factoring is very saturated, fewer companies will pop-up during the outlook period. The overall number of establishments will fall by more than 100 from 2023 to 2028. Fewer entrants into the Invoice Factoring industry will hinder internal competition, enabling large players to consolidate and gain more market share. Falling revenue will also encourage smaller businesses to exit the industry, raising consolidation. Big invoice factoring companies will be able to more effectively adopt new technology and offer more efficient financial products since they'll be less focused on competing with smaller businesses over price, quality and reputation, providing new revenue streams for existing players.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Increased Productivity Growth During the Outlook Period
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Increased productivity growth during the outlook period will spur financial innovation, making it easier for businesses to borrow money. Soaring access to credit will make it easier for customers to borrow money from commercial banks and other traditional financial institutions, providing another stream of revenue for the industry's competitors.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Constantly Shifting Interest Rates Will Enhance Revenue Volatility
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Higher interest rates discourage consumers from purchasing traditional financial products and increase demand for invoice factoring, while lower interest rates do the opposite, so the cost of borrowing is a major determinant of the strength of the Invoice Factoring industry's substitutes. Interest rates are projected to be somewhat volatile in the near future, as potential foreign conflicts, political events and trade disputes might encourage the Federal Reserve to alter its policies. These shifts have the potential to cause big swings in revenue for invoice factoring companies in the United States.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Greater Consumer Knowledge About Financial Products May Present Long Term Challenges
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As financial innovation increases and more individuals become interested in managing their money meticulously, knowledge of financial products among consumers will rise in the coming years. The general public gaining a greater understanding of financial products will spike interest in invoice factoring among some business owners, providing a new revenue stream for the industry during the outlook period. Alternatively, since new and existing financial products will become more advanced because of innovation, they'll take up a larger share of the market in the future. Businesses with better knowledge of financial products will use them since they're aware of their higher returns, threatening revenue for invoice factoring companies in the long term.

industry_definition: Invoice factoring companies specialize in short-term debt financing. Factoring involves a company selling its account receivables to a third party to access cash to finance further business activity without having to wait for its debtors to pay them. Companies generate revenue through factor fees (the difference between the price paid for the invoice and money received from debtors).
key_trends: Invoice factoring companies did very poorly during the current period. Increased access to credit has siphoned revenue off to substitutes and COVID-19 crashed the US economy.
Long-term trends will be harmful to the industry. Greater public knowledge of financial products and increased external competition will cause revenue to decline during the outlook period.

Invoice factoring companies are subject to a host of regulations used for financial institutions. Smaller invoice factoring operators are designated as nonbank systemically important financial institutions (nonbank SIFIs), so they're regulated by the Dodd-Frank Act.

The industry doesn't receive much assistance, but there are some private and governmental organizations that help out. One private association that aids invoice factoring companies is the Secured Finance Network (SFNet).

Most product segments have risen as a percentage of revenue, except for recourse factoring. Concerns regarding high inflation, rising interest rates and recessionary fears have pushed businesses away from this type of financing as they become more risk-averse.

Since the need to transport goods has surged after the pandemic recovery, demand for invoice factoring from transportation and distribution companies has risen. As interest rates have gone up, the level of construction has declined, so spending on the industry's services from construction companies has fallen.

The Southeast's high population makes it naturally suited to invoice factoring. Since regions with large populations contain many different businesses, some will need invoice factoring, causing the industry to be prevalent in the region.

The Southwest region has many businesses that are unbanked, which means they don't have access to traditional means of financing. Since these companies need another type of financing, demand for invoice factoring is high in the region.

Invoice factoring is less traditional than other financial institutions, such as investment banks and private equity firms. Companies haven't had as much time to consolidate since the industry is newer, so market share concentration remains low.

Since most downstream companies that use invoice factoring operate locally, most companies in the industry serve one specific region. The regionalization of invoice factoring companies keeps market share concentration muted and increases internal competition nationwide.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Non-Recourse Factoring Has Become More Popular Since COVID-19
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Non-recourse factoring involves a company selling its invoices to the factoring company, where all risks associated with unpaid invoices are transferred to the industry. To compensate for increased risk, invoice factoring companies will charge their clients higher factor fees and offer lower advance rates, which is the percentage of the invoice value that the factoring company pays their clients at the beginning of the sale. Invoice factoring companies engage in non-recourse factoring with small, medium-sized and corporate clients. Since COVID-19 caused major economic disruptions, companies wanted to reduce risk by receiving the value of their debt in funds, causing non-recourse factoring's revenue share to soar during the current period.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: The High Risk Associated With Recourse Factoring Makes It Undesirable
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Recourse factoring is the opposite of non-recourse factoring, as the client is still liable for unpaid invoices even after it sells its debt to the factoring company. Invoice factoring companies offer high advance rates and reduced factor fees to compensate for more risk. Recent volatile economic conditions (e.g., high inflation, recessionary fears, rising interest rates) have made corporations more risk averse, so recourse factoring's revenue share has fallen during the current period.

Reverse factoring involves debtors seeking services from invoice factoring companies instead of lenders. As debt has risen throughout the economy, more debtors are seeking invoice factoring services, so reverse factoring's revenue share has increased during the current period.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Demand for Invoice Factoring From Manufacturers Depends on Industrial Production
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Manufacturers that use invoice factoring services include makers of apparel, chemicals, consumer electronics, home furnishings and other products. Manufacturers sell invoices to the industry so they can use cash to buy materials in bulk and keep up their operations. Since more industrial production increases manufacturing output, manufacturers will demand invoice factoring services in greater quantities when the industrial production index (IPI) rises. The IPI has been volatile during the current period because of COVID-19, the pandemic recovery and high inflation, so manufacturers' revenue share has fluctuated significantly but hasn't grown or declined during the current period.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Spending From Distribution and Transportation Companies Has Surged as the Economy Has Recovered
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Distribution and transportation operators that use invoice factoring include trucking and other related companies. It can take months for these companies to receive the cash for dropping off goods, so they rely on the industry to provide them with immediate funding. Spending from these companies has skyrocketed since the recovery from COVID-19 has raised demand for transportation and distribution, causing this segment's revenue share to expand during the current period.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Revenue From Construction Companies Has Plunged Because of High-Interest Rates
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Construction companies use invoice factoring services because they need extra cash to cover costs such as lawsuits and overtime hours.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Funds From Miscellaneous Industries Tend to Be Steady
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Other operators that use invoice factoring are healthcare companies and educational organizations that sell services, along with utilities, communications and other companies. There's often consistent demand from these industries, as they're necessary for the functioning of the economy, so spending from them has risen and fallen with revenue. As a result, their revenue share has held steady during the current period.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region is home to big states such as Florida, Georgia, Virginia and Tennessee, so the area as a whole comprises the largest portion of the country's population. Since regions with more people contain a diverse slew of businesses, many different financing options are necessary, resulting in the prevalence of many invoice factoring companies. Some Southeastern states (e.g., Georgia, Mississippi, Louisiana) have very high unbanked rates, so some consumers and businesses don't have access to traditional banking, making invoice factoring more essential in the region.

The Southwest region (specifically Texas and New Mexico) suffers from the same problem many Southeastern states have, as many businesses and households don't use traditional banking. The unbanked rate might be elevated in some of these states because of the high concentration of undocumented immigrants. Undocumented migrants don't want to use traditional banking because they're at risk of deportation if they disclose their personal or financial information. Households and businesses with high unbanked rates search for other means of financing, which raises demand for invoice factoring.

The Mid-Atlantic region is home to major cities such as Philadelphia, New York and Washington DC. Since these cities are large, densely populated and diverse, many types of businesses operate in this region. Some of these businesses will require untraditional forms of financing, so invoice factoring has a presence in the Mid-Atlantic.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Federal Reserve supervises and regulates US banks and bank holding companies that offer invoice factoring services.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC)
regulations_points.regulation_description: The OCC is the main regulator of all federal and state-chartered institutions that offer invoice factoring services.
The FDIC requires bank holding and savings and loan holding companies that offer invoice factoring to put money into the Depositor Insurance Fund.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (Dodd-Frank)
regulations_points.regulation_description: Dodd-Frank requires that many small invoice factoring companies maintain a safe level of capital and liquidity and are subject to examinations.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market or produce a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Companies in the invoice factoring industry provide a growing range of factoring and invoice discounting services, as well as micro-loans and lines of credit.

FAQs.question: Are your sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Revenue for the industry depends on business sentiment, as businesses turn to companies in the industry for short-term working capital, loans and invoice financing.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: The industry lacks volatility, as the company largely serves the vast network of small businesses throughout the economy, rather than undiversified mutlinationals that are exposed to global economic risk.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities in locations with well-established infrastructure networks?
FAQs.answer: Companies in the industry are best-located near business centers and underbanked regions.

FAQs.question: Does your company use advanced software systems for operations?
FAQs.answer: Innovative companies in this industry use machine learning technology to ascertain creditworthiness for invoice financing.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs by automating operations over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: The implementation of innovative technologies in the industry have reduced the need for extraneous human labor.

FAQs.question: How does your company stay compliant with industry regulations?
FAQs.answer: Lending requirements dictated by OCC, FDIC and Federal Reserve maintain stability in markets for short-term credit financing.

FAQs.question: What risks does your company face regarding liquidity and capital adequacy?
FAQs.answer: Financing invoices for companies that lack creditworthiness can cause companies in this industry to become insolvent. Also, unfair terms for borrowers can cause downstream small businesses to become insolvent.

FAQs.question: How does your company compensate for the dependence of cash flow on the economy?
FAQs.answer: The company ensures high lending standards to ensure all invoice financing activity has a high chance of repayment. The company also offers micro loans and lines of credit to diversify revenue.

FAQs.question: Rising interest rates have increased the costs of borrowing short-term capital from commercial banks. Many small businesses have turned to invoice factoring as a cheaper and more flexible form of short-term financing.
FAQs.answer: Rising interest rates have increased the costs of borrowing short-term capital from commercial banks. Many small businesses have turned to invoice factoring as a cheaper and more flexible form of short-term financing.

FAQs.question: Are you located in a densely populated area? How close are you to your nearest competitors?
FAQs.answer: Companies compete on their ability to provide clients with easy access to capital to meet their financial needs.

FAQs.question: What markets do you target? Is your demand concentrated in any one market? How can you diversify your client base?
FAQs.answer: Companies that provide invoice discounting services to a range of clients in various industries benefit from a degree of protection against a downturn in one of its main markets.

FAQs.question: Do you offer a wide variety of products compared to your competitors? How do you monitor what investment opportunities your customers want?
FAQs.answer: Invoice discounting providers need to have excellent interest rate, credit and operational risk management processes.

FAQs.question: Do you regularly keep track of trends in credit? How will you take advantage of rising interest rates?
FAQs.answer: Changes in the interest rate charged on most of a bank's products stem from changes in the prime rate. When interest rates increase, traditional loan products become more expensive, improving the competitive advantage of nonbank financing provided by operators.

FAQs.question: How do fluctuations in business sentiment affect your business? Do you track the business sentiment index?
FAQs.answer: Access to credit is calculated as the borrowing capacity advanced by commercial banks in the form of loans, cash credit and overdrafts. Increases in access to credit denote an improving aggregate lending market and a more robust economy, which benefits small businesses.

FAQs.question: Do you regularly monitor trends in corporate profit? How do you market your services to businesses?
FAQs.answer: Increases in corporate profit typically indicate an improving macroeconomic landscape. In addition, mounting corporate profit levels tend to reduce the risk involved in lending, as businesses are in the financial standing to more easily pay off their debt.
